title: Mum's claim that smacking son once 'changed relationship' sparks furious debate online
text:

A mum sparked a furious debate online today after claiming that her relationship changed with her son after smacking him once.

Broadcaster Rebecca Wilcox appeared on This Morning to debate new Scottish legislation banning smoking, which she agrees with.

Meanwhile fellow mum and journalist Clare Muldoon said that she objected to the law.

Speaking to hosts Eamonn Holmes and Ruth Langsford, Rebecca said that he "biggest guilt" as a mum was that she once smacked her four-year-old.

"It was all to do with my loss of control," she said. "Yeah, he was misbehaving, yes he was doing something wrong, but I'm the adult, I should know better.

(Image: ITV)

(Image: ITV)

"I'm constantly saying don't hit your brothers, don't hit your friends, don't hit me. And what am I doing? Biggest hypocrite in the world.

"I smacked him - not hard, didn't leave a mark - but the fear in his eyes and the relationship changed and there was an effect... he started hitting more."

However Clare said: "I think there's a very fine line between the state interfering with parental responsibility."

She added that she felt as though it was "big brother honing in".

Unsurprisingly, this sparked a huge debate online with opposing viewpoints.

(Image: ITV)

(Image: ITV)

One tweeted: "Once again we are becoming more of a nanny state. 99% + are responsible parents who risk being prosecuted for discipling their children. You feeling guilty is not a reason to stop the rest of us parenting the way we feel is proportionate #nannystate #ThisMorning."

Another agreed, commenting: "#ThisMorning @ITV I'm 20 year old and our parents lightly smacked us if we were misbehaving but it hasn't made me hostile or disrespectful to adults. Also out family is really close."

However a third remarked: "We can discipline a child without smacking them. How can anyone advocate resorting to violence to communicate with a child?! 'It never did me any harm'?!? People have no idea how experiencing smacking as a child, unconsciously affects them as an adult #thismorning."

Another wrote: "#thismorning I agree no smacking is best but not sure how this law will be enforced. Surely they’re not expecting social workers to go out to every smacked child? If so they’ll need to pull in more resources as priority will be children at significant risk of harm."

While one fumed: "#ThisMorning Ban smacking, what’s next? Being punished onto a “ naughty step, taking toys away or not going to a fun event” will be mental abuse..."

*This Morning airs weekdays at 10.30am on ITV
description: Broadcaster Rebecca Wilcox appeared on This Morning to debate new Scottish legislation banning smoking
